{{Infobox officeholder |name = Håkan Jeppsson |image = |imagesize = |alt = |caption = |order = 12th |office = Chairman of Malmö FF |term_start = 18 February 2010 |term_end = |predecessor = [[Bengt Madsen]] |successor = |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1961|5|6|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Malmö]], Sweden |death_date = |death_place = |birthname = |alma_mater = [[Lund University]] |occupation = [[CEO]] |profession = [[Businessman]] |website = [https://web.archive.org/web/20120310080149/http://www.mff.se/Ditt_MFF/Om_klubben/Styrelse/Hakan%20Jeppsson.aspx Håkan Jeppsson at mff.se] |footnotes = }} '''Håkan Lennart Jeppsson''' (born 6 May 1961) is a Swedish [[businessman]] who is currently the chairman of the Swedish [[Association football]] club [[Malmö FF]], a post he has held since 2010. Jeppsson received his education at [[Lund University]] and works as [[CEO]] for Inwido.<ref name="Facts">{{cite web|url= http://www.mff.se/Ditt_MFF/Om_klubben/Styrelse/Hakan%20Jeppsson.aspx|title= Håkan Jeppsson|accessdate= 25 June 2012|work= mff.se|publisher= Malmö FF|language= Swedish|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20120310080149/http://www.mff.se/Ditt_MFF/Om_klubben/Styrelse/Hakan%20Jeppsson.aspx|archivedate= 10 March 2012|df= }}</ref>
==Career==
===Sport career=== In his younger years Jeppsson played football at Malmö FF simultaneously as he played [[table tennis]] at IK Pallas. After a couple of years being active in both sports he decided to quit football in favour of becoming a professional table tennis player. Jeppsson had his active career at the same time as Sweden was dominating the table tennis world in the 1970s and the 1980s. After growing tired of the life as a professional player he decided to focus on a civil career and started studying international economy at [[Lund University]].<ref name="Facts" />
===Civil career=== After graduating he worked his way up to higher positions. Jeppsson was the president of Papyrus AB from 1999 to 2002. He later went on to become the president and CEO of BE group. Jeppsson has been the president and CEO of Inwido since 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.inwido.se/sv/content/styrelsen |title=Styrelsen |accessdate=25 June 2012 |work=inwido.se |publisher=Inwido |language=Swedish |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120329220102/http://www.inwido.se/sv/content/styrelsen |archivedate=29 March 2012 |df= }}</ref>
===Chairman of Malmö FF=== Jeppsson was elected a board member of Malmö FF in 2004. Eventually he was elected vice chairman under [[Bengt Madsen]]. In 2010 when Madsen decided not to stand for re-election Jeppsson was the only candidate to succeed him and did so on 18 February 2010.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.sydsvenskan.se/sport/fotboll/mff/hakan-jeppsson-tar-over-mff/|title= Håkan Jeppsson tar över MFF|date=19 February 2010|accessdate=25 June 2012 |work=sydsvenskan.se|publisher= Sydsvenskan|language = Swedish}}</ref> In his first year as chairman and the same year as the club's centennial anniversary Malmö FF won its 16th [[List of Swedish football champions|Swedish championship]].
Malmö FF had completed the move from former home stadium [[Malmö Stadion]] to [[Swedbank Stadion]] a year before Jeppsson's presidency began. The new stadium created both financial opportunities as well as certain risks for the club. These risks became apparent when the club announced that the loss for the [[2010 Malmö FF season|2010 season]] was 30 million [[Swedish krona|kronor]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.sydsvenskan.se/sport/fotboll/mff/mffs-pelle-svensson-avgar/|title= MFF:s Pelle Svensson avgår|date=24 March 2011|accessdate=25 June 2012 |work=sydsvenskan.se|publisher= Sydsvenskan|language = Swedish}}</ref> As a result, the club sacked its current managing director and Jeppsson announced that there would be several austerity measures to turn the result back to positive. As part of the plan Malmö FF increased their share in Swedbank Stadion to 75% to reduce costs and increase profits.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.sydsvenskan.se/sport/fotboll/mff-utokar-agandet-i-stadion|title= MFF utökar ägandet i stadion|date=13 June 2012|accessdate=25 June 2012 |work=sydsvenskan.se|publisher= Sydsvenskan|language = Swedish}}</ref>
==Honours won by club during presidency== *[[Allsvenskan]]: **Winners (5): [[2010 Allsvenskan|2010]], [[2013 Allsvenskan|2013]], [[2014 Allsvenskan|2014]], [[2016 Allsvenskan|2016]], [[2017 Allsvenskan|2017]] *[[Svenska Supercupen]]: **Winners (2): [[2013 Svenska Supercupen|2013]], [[2014 Svenska Supercupen|2014]] **Runner-up (1): [[2011 Svenska Supercupen|2011]] *[[Svenska Cupen]]: **Runner-up (1): [[2015–16 Svenska Cupen|2015–16]]
== References == {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}}

{{Infobox person |name = Joseph D. Hackmey |image = Joseph Hackmey.JPG |occupation = Chairman, Hackmey Group |networth = £300 million<ref>Cahlil, Julia. (2 October 2012). [http://www.egi.co.uk/news/rich-list-2011-homepage-1/ Rich List 2011: homepage]. [[Estates Gazette]].</ref><ref>(26 April 2009). [https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/joseph-hackmey-and-family-zc9zh75mxsl Joseph Hackmey and family]. [[The Sunday Times]].</ref> }} '''Joseph D. Hackmey''' is an Israeli [[businessman]], [[insurance company]] executive, [[actuary]], [[investor]], and an [[art]] and [[stamp collector]]. [[Art News]] listed Hackmey as one of the 200 biggest art collectors in the world.<ref>[http://www.artnews.com/2008/07/01/the-artnews-200-top-collectors-2008/ The 2008 Artnews 200 top collectors]. [[ARTnews]].</ref> He was the Chairman of Israel Phoenix. <ref name="Sami Peretz">Peretz, Sami. (27 December 2002). [http://www.themarker.com/markets/1.130496 "Life Work in return to cash"], [[The Marker]]</ref> Chairman of the Israeli Insurance Association and Chairman of the Israeli Life Offices Association. <ref name="TAU Insider">Profile: [http://www.tau.ac.il/bog/TAU_Insider_09.pdf "An Important Contribution to Western Civilization"], at Tau Insider 2009, p. 16.</ref>
==Biography== Joseph Hackmey is a 5th generation Israeli.<ref name="Sami Peretz"/> His grandfather, Joseph Hackmey Shvili directed [[Barclays bank]] – then the largest bank in [[Mandatory Palestine]]. His second grandfather, Moshe Carasso, was a prominent businessman in Palestine. His father, David, established an [[Insurance broker|assurance agency]] in 1943, when he was 24 years old. In 1949 Hackmey turned his assurance agency into an assurance company. At the time, his partners were the English Phoenix Assurance Company and the [[Israel Discount Bank]].<ref name="Sami Peretz"/>
Hackmey was born in [[Tel Aviv]]<ref name="academie dephilatelie">[http://www.academiedephilatelie.fr/timbres/membre.php?rub=13 Biography in academie de philatelite site] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150725221402/http://academiedephilatelie.fr/bio-membres/hackmey.htm |date=2015-07-25 }}</ref> to a [[Sephardi Jews|Sepharadi]]-[[Jerusalem]]ite family on his father's side and a Sepharadi-Greek-Italian family on his mother's side.<ref name="Dalia Karpel">Karpel, Dalia. (November 2, 1995). "If it's beautiful, I want it to be mine", Musaf [[Haaretz]].</ref> His sister, Nitza Kanfer,<ref name="Shlomi Sheffer">Sheffer, Shlomi (1 January 2003). [http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/business/hackmey-sells-the-family-firm-1.23632 "Hackmey sells the family firm"]. [[Haaretz]]</ref> is 12 years younger than him.
Hackmey attended [[Boarding school]]s in Switzerland.<ref name="Dalia Karpel"/> He earned a B.Sc. degree in [[mathematics]] at [[M.I.T.]] in 1964. He continued his studies at M.I.T. and earned an M.sc. degree in [[electrical engineering]] in 1965, at the age of 20.<ref name="academie dephilatelie"/> An honorary post-graduate diploma in [[actuarial science]] and [[business administration]] from the Hebrew University of Jerusalem was awarded in 1967.<ref name="Honorary doctorate">[http://www.tau.ac.il/honordoc/joseph_hackmey.pdf Honorary doctorate for Hackmey in Tel Aviv University site]</ref> Hackmey received an MA in Judaic Studies from [[New York University]] in 2013.
Hackmey knows seven languages.<ref name="Ilan Nachshon">Nachshon, Ilan. (October 30, 1998). "Love, passion and obsession". 7 days Yedioth Ahronoth. P. 56.</ref>
==Business career== Hackmey commenced his insurance career in 1968 with the Israel Phoenix Assurance company. After seven years he was appointed by the [[board of directors]] as chief executive officer of the Phoenix. Four years after he appointed as CEO the Phoenix profits multiplied by five times.<ref name="Ilan Nachshon"/> He was elected [[Chairman]] of the Israeli Insurance Association twice and Chairman of the Israeli Life Offices Association twice.<ref name="TAU Insider"/> When his father died in 1991, Hackmey succeeded him as the Chairman of Israel Phoenix.<ref name="Sami Peretz"/> In 2002 Hackmey and his sister sold their stake of 56.8% in the Israel Phoenix Assurance company, for 314 million US$.<ref name="Shlomi Sheffer"/> At the time, it was the third largest insurance company in Israel. It was sold to the brothers in law, [[Ya'akov Shahar]] and Israel Kez, the importers of Volvo cars to Israel and the owners of [[Maccabi Haifa F.C.|Maccabi Haifa football team]].<ref name="Moshe Ronen"/>
==Art collection== In 1994, a London-based art news magazine named Hackmey "Art Collector of the year".<ref name="Dalia Karpel"/> The Israel Phoenix corporate collection, consisting of 2,200 items, most of them paintings and a small quantity of sculptures, was estimated in 2002 to be worth 216 million shekels.<ref name="Moshe Ronen">Ronen, Moshe. (4 September 2002). "Painting in the eye of the storm". 24 hours, [[Yedioth Ahronot]]. pp. 14-15.</ref> The international collection included [[Picasso]], [[Matisse]], [[Robert Rauschenberg]], [[Barnett Newman]], [[Jasper Johns]], [[Jean Dubuffet]], [[Mark Rothko]].<ref name="Moshe Ronen"/><ref name="The stamp">(26 June 2015). [https://www.paulfrasercollectibles.com/blogs/art-photography/the-stamp-and-art-collections-of-joseph-hackmey "The stamp and art collections of Joseph Hackmey"]. in paulfrasercollectibles.com</ref> The Israeli collection included [[Reuven Rubin]], [[Yehezkel Streichman]], [[Arie Aroch]], [[Joseph Zaritsky]], [[Yitzhak Danziger]], [[Marcel Janco]], [[Mordecai Ardon]], [[Aviva Uri]], [[Raffi Lavie]], [[Avigdor Stematsky]].<ref name="Ilan Nachshon"/><ref>Sheffi, Smadar (24 November 1998). "Like a clock". [[Haaretz]]</ref>
Professor Mordechai Omer, director of the [[Tel Aviv Museum of Art]], studied the collection and published a selection of it in a 600-page book. In 1998 Tel Aviv Museum of Art organized an exhibition which included 300 items from the collection.<ref name="Moshe Ronen"/>
Hackmey also possesses a large personal collection of international art and Israeli art, including a special collection of young Israeli artists.<ref name="Dalia Karpel"/>
==Philately== Hackmey is an enthusiastic [[Philately|philatelist]]. His collections <ref name="The stamp"/> of [[Ceylon]] and [[New Zealand]] Commonwealth stamps considered to be the finest ever assembled for those countries, and Hackmey was presented with an International Award in recognition for his record. Hackmey's most remarkable purchase, is a November 11, 1858 issue of Romanian newspaper [[Zimbrul și Vulturul]]. The item bears eight rare Romanian cap de bour ("Bull's Head") stamps, issued by the principality of [[Moldova]] in 1858. He won the Grand Prix National and a Large Gold Medal at the Efiro 2008 in Bucharest for his exhibit Classical Romania. He also owned a May 1851 cover widely considered to be the greatest USA Classic cover in existence.
He also won Grand Prix medals at the World Philatelic Exhibitions, Istanbul 1996, Israel 1998, Israel 2008, and was a candidate for the Grand Prix in Washington, 2006.<ref>[http://www.japhila.cz/pdf/palmares.pdf World Philatelic Exhibition: Washington 2006 - Palmares]</ref>
Hackmey is a Fellow of the [[Royal Philatelic Society]], London and a member of the Collectors Club of New York. In 2010 he was elected an associate foreign member of the [[Académie de philatélie]], Paris.<ref name="academie dephilatelie"/>
==Philanthropy== The [[Bnai Brith]] International organization awarded Hackmey the "Bnai Brith International Humanitarian award". In 2009 he received an [[honorary doctorate]] degree from the Tel Aviv University in recognition of his various contributions to Israeli society, including art, music and culture.<ref name="Honorary doctorate"/>
Hackmey is a member of the board of governors of the [[Weizmann Institute of Science]],<ref>[http://www.weizmann.ac.il/board/members/international-board List of international board members], Weizmann institute of science</ref> the [[Israel Museum]], the [[Tel Aviv Museum]],<ref>[http://www.tamuseum.org.il/board-of-governers International Board of Governors], Tel Aviv Museum of art</ref> the [[Tel Aviv University]],<ref>[http://www1.tau.ac.il/bog/members.php Members of the Board of Governors], Tel Aviv University</ref> the [[Hebrew University of Jerusalem]],<ref name="Dalia Karpel"/> the [[Israeli Opera]],<ref>[http://www.israel-opera.co.il/israeli-opera-season14-15/files/assets/basic-html/page57.html Friends of the Israeli Opera] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304111229/http://www.israel-opera.co.il/israeli-opera-season14-15/files/assets/basic-html/page57.html |date=2016-03-04 }}</ref> the [[Israeli Philharmonic Orchestra]], and is a member of the International Council of the [[Tate Gallery]] of London. He served as the Chairman of the Israeli Chess Association, and during his chairmanship, the number of Israeli international chess grandmasters had increased from 5 to 29.<ref name="TAU Insider"/>
He established Hackmey Hebrew Classical Library, joined its two world-famous predecessors at [[Harvard University Press]] – the [[Loeb Classical Library]]. it will offer classical texts – in the case of the Hackmey Library, Hebrew and Aramaic in facing-page translation.<ref name="TAU Insider"/>
==See also== * [[Zimbrul și Vulturul]] *[[Visual arts in Israel]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *Vogel, Carol. (October 11, 2002). [https://www.nytimes.com/2002/10/11/arts/inside-art.html "INSIDE ART"]. [[The New York Times]]. *Cahlil, Julia. (2 October 2012). [http://www.egi.co.uk/news/rich-list-2011-homepage-1/ Rich List 2011: homepage] in [[Estates Gazette]]. *[https://www.justcollecting.com/miscellania/the-stamp-and-art-collections-of-joseph-hackmey The stamp and art collections of Joseph Hackmey] in justcollecting.com {{Authority control}}

{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2016}} {{Infobox person | name = Juanita Broaddrick | birth_name = Juanita Smith | birth_date = | nationality = [[United States|American]] | residence = [[Van Buren, Arkansas]], U.S. | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = [[Nursing home]] administrator | spouse = Gary Hickey (?–1979) (divorced)
{{Marriage|David Broaddrick|1981|2004|end=div}} | children = Kevin Hickey (born 1969)
grandson
two granddaughters }} '''Juanita Broaddrick''' is an American former [[nursing home]] administrator. In 1999, she alleged that [[President of the United States|U.S. President]] [[Bill Clinton]] raped her in April 1978 when he was the attorney general of Arkansas. Clinton's attorney, [[David E. Kendall|David Kendall]] denied the allegations on his client's behalf. Clinton declined to comment further on the issue. Rumors circulated about Broaddrick's allegations for many years, but she refused to speak to the media. In a sworn statement in 1997 with the [[Jane Doe|placeholder name]] "Jane Doe #5",{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/politics/special/clinton/stories/janedoe022099.htm|title=Another Clinton Accuser Goes Public|last=Romano |first=Lois|date=February 20, 1999|newspaper=Washington Post|last2=Baker|first2=Peter}} Broaddrick filed an [[affidavit]] with [[Paula Jones]]' lawyers stating there were unfounded rumors and stories circulating "that Mr. Clinton had made unwelcome sexual advances toward me in the late seventies. ... These allegations are untrue".{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/politics/special/clinton/stories/affidavit122398.htm|title=Affidavit From Jane Doe #5|last=Broaddrick|first=Juanita|date=January 2, 1998|work=Washington Post}} Speculation continued that Broaddrick had more to say on the matter, and in an interview with ''[[Dateline NBC]]'' that aired on February 24, 1999, Broaddrick told her story in public in full for the first time, this time stating that Clinton had indeed raped her.''Dateline NBC'': February 24, 1999. ''The Washington Post'' [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/politics/special/clinton/stories/broaddrick022599.htm published a story about the interview] on February 25, 1999. It is the most serious of the claims that emerged during the 1990s comprising the [[Bill Clinton sexual misconduct allegations]]. Broaddrick's claims have received new attention as a consequence of the [[Hillary Clinton presidential campaign, 2016]] and the 2017 [[Me Too (hashtag)|#MeToo phenomenon]]. ==Background== Broaddrick is from [[Van Buren, Arkansas]], a town in the northwest part of the state. She was born Juanita Smith to parents Buster Smith and Mary Elizabeth Smith.http://www.ockerputmanfuneralhome.com/book-of-memories/609508/Smith-Mary/obituary.php?Printable=true She has an older sister. Her father owned the Smith Cleaners establishment. The family belonged to the [[Episcopal Church (United States)|Episcopal Church]]. In her memoir she says her mother was physically and emotionally abusive to her and her sister.''You'd Better Put Some Ice On That'', pp 12–14 Juanita Smith graduated from [[Van Buren High School (Van Buren, Arkansas)|Van Buren High School]] in 1960.{{cite web|url=http://www.classmates.com/yearbooks/Van-Buren-High-School/232615|title=1960 Van Buren High School Yearbook|website=www.classmates.com|accessdate=June 15, 2018}} She attended nursing school at Sparks School of Nursing from 1960 to 1963. She then worked as a [[registered nurse]] at several [[nursing home]]s.{{cite web|url=http://shadowgov.com/Clinton/DNBCJuanitaTranscript.html|title=ShadowGov – Clinton Rapist / Dateline NBC Transcript|publisher=}} In 1974 she decided she wanted to run a nursing home herself and so she bought one in Van Buren.Dorothy Rabinowitz, "Juanita Broaddrick Meets the Press", The Wall Street Journal, February 19, 1999 It was known as the Brownwood Manor Nursing Home.{{cite web|url=http://www.weeklystandard.com/the-auditing-of-juanita-broaddrick/article/12132|title=The Auditing of Juanita Broaddrick|date=June 12, 2000|work=Weekly Standard|accessdate=June 15, 2018}} Her mother was part owner with her. Juanita was first married to Gary Hickey, with the marriage happening before she left nursing school.ibid, p 22 They had a son who was born around 1969. At the time of the alleged 1978 rape, she was having an affair with David Broaddrick, who also was married to another person.[http://www.wnd.com/2005/05/30492/ "The Rape of Juanita Broaddrick"], ''[[wnd.com]]'', May 26, 2005. With excerpt about Broaddrick from Candice Jackson's book, ''Their Lives: The Women Targeted by the Clinton Machine''. ==Allegations against Bill Clinton== ===1978: Her account=== Broaddrick, who was known as Juanita Hickey at the time, first met Clinton when he made a visit to her nursing home during his [[Arkansas gubernatorial election, 1978|1978 gubernatorial campaign]]. Clinton was [[Arkansas Attorney General]] at the time. Broaddrick wanted to volunteer for the campaign, and says Clinton invited her to stop by the campaign office in [[Little Rock, Arkansas|Little Rock]].Barringer, Felicity; Firestone, David (February 24, 1999). [https://www.nytimes.com/1999/02/24/us/on-tortuous-route-sexual-assault-accusation-against-clinton-resurfaces.html "On Tortuous Route, Sexual Assault Accusation Against Clinton Resurfaces"]. ''[[The New York Times]]''. She contacted the office a few weeks later while in the area for a nursing home conference. Clinton said he would not be in the campaign office that day and suggested they meet at her hotel's coffee shop instead. Upon his arrival, however, he allegedly requested that they instead have coffee in her room to avoid a crowd of reporters in the lobby. Broaddrick agreed. Broaddrick says the two spoke briefly in her room, with Clinton describing plans to renovate a prison visible from her window if he became governor. Then, according to Broaddrick, Clinton suddenly kissed her. Broaddrick says she pushed Clinton away and told him she was married and not interested, but he persisted. As recounted in the NBC interview: {{quote|text=Then he tries to kiss me again. And the second time he tries to kiss me he starts biting my lip ... He starts to, um, bite on my top lip and I tried to pull away from him. And then he forces me down on the bed. And I just was very frightened, and I tried to get away from him and I told him 'No,' that I didn't want this to happen but he wouldn't listen to me. ... It was a real panicky, panicky situation. I was even to the point where I was getting very noisy, you know, yelling to 'Please stop.' And that's when he pressed down on my right shoulder and he would bite my lip. ... When everything was over with, he got up and straightened himself, and I was crying at the moment and he walks to the door, and calmly puts on his sunglasses. And before he goes out the door he says 'You better get some ice on that.' And he turned and went out the door.}} When asked if there was any way Clinton could have thought it was consensual, Broaddrick said "No, not with what I told him and with how I tried to push him away. It was not consensual." Broaddrick shared the hotel room with her friend and employee Norma Rogers. Rogers attended a conference seminar that morning, and says she returned to their room to find Broaddrick on the bed "in a state of shock," her pantyhose torn in the crotch and her lip swollen as though she had been hit. Rogers says Broaddrick told her Clinton had "forced himself on her." Rogers helped Broaddrick ice her lip, and then the women left Little Rock. Rogers said that Broaddrick was very upset on the way home and blamed herself for letting Clinton in the room. Broaddrick says she did not tell her husband, Gary Hickey, about the incident, and told him she accidentally injured her lip. He told NBC he did not remember the injury or her explanation.[http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/explainer/1999/03/is_juanita_broaddrick_telling_the_truth.html "Is Juanita Broaddrick Telling the Truth?"]. ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]''. March 3, 1999. David Broaddrick, however, has said he noticed her injured lip, and she told him that Clinton had raped her when he asked about it. Three other friends confirmed that Broaddrick had told them about the incident at the time: Susan Lewis, Louis Ma, and Jean Darden, Norma Rogers' sister. Broaddrick did not recall the date of the alleged incident, but said it was spring of 1978 and that she had stayed in the Camelot Hotel. Records show Broaddrick attended a nursing home meeting at the Camelot Hotel in Little Rock on April 25, 1978. The Clinton White House would not respond to requests for Clinton's official schedule for the date, but news reports suggest that he was in Little Rock that day, with no official commitments in the morning. Three weeks after the alleged assault, Broaddrick participated in a small Clinton fundraiser at the home of a local dentist. Broaddrick said she was "in denial" and felt guilty, thinking that she had given Clinton the wrong idea by letting him into her room. When she arrived at the event, she says, her friend who had picked the Clintons up from the airport told her that [[Hillary Clinton]] had asked if she would be at the event. Broaddrick says Bill Clinton did not speak to her at the event, but Hillary Clinton approached her, took her hand, and said "I just want you to know how much Bill and I appreciate what you do for him." When Broaddrick moved her hand away, she says, Hillary Clinton held on to her and said, "Do you understand? Everything that you do." Broaddrick says she felt nauseated and left the gathering. Broaddrick says she interpreted the incident as Hillary Clinton thanking her for keeping quiet.{{Cite web|url=https://www.vox.com/2016/1/6/10722580/bill-clinton-juanita-broaddrick|title=The rape allegation against Bill Clinton, explained|last=Matthews|first=Dylan|date=November 14, 2017|website=[[Vox (website)|Vox]]}}Abramson, Jill (October 11, 2016). [https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/oct/11/hillary-clinton-bill-accusers-jones-willey-broaddrick "Did Hillary Clinton intimidate Bill's accusers? Let's look at the evidence"]. ''[[The Guardian]]''.[[Hannity, Sean]] (June 10, 2003). [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5KZ8ICvutc0 "HILLARY THREATENED JUANITA BROADDRICK 2 WEEKS AFTER RAPE"]. [[Fox News]]. Posted to [[YouTube]] March 27, 2007. ===Subsequent developments=== She divorced Hickey around 1979 and married David Broaddrick around 1981. Broaddrick opened a second facility, to provide services for mentally disabled children in [[Fort Smith, Arkansas]]. In 1984, Broaddrick's nursing facility was adjudged the best in the state, which brought a congratulatory official letter from the governor. On the bottom was a handwritten note from Clinton, saying, "I admire you very much."''Wall Street Journal'': [https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB919379691540145000 Juanita Broaddrick Meets the Press]. February 19, 1999. Broaddrick said that in 1991, Clinton called her out of a state nursing standards meeting to try to apologize: "'Juanita, I'm so sorry for what I did. I'm not the man that I used to be, can you ever forgive me? What can I do to make this up to you?' And I'm standing there in absolute shock. And I told him to go to hell, and I walked off."Kurtz, Howard (February 25, 1999). [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/politics/special/clinton/stories/broaddrick022599.htm "Clinton Accuser's Story Aired"]. ''[[Washington Post]]''. p. A15. Jean Darden, in whom Broaddrick had confided about the incident, also attended the meeting, and said she saw Broaddrick talking to Clinton in the hallway. Clinton announced [[Bill Clinton presidential campaign, 1992|his 1992 presidential campaign]] soon after that alleged interaction. ===1992–1998=== Though Broaddrick was resistant to talking to the media, rumors about her story began circulating no later than Clinton's presidential bid in 1992. Broaddrick had confided in Phillip Yoakum, whom she knew from business circles and at the time considered a friend. When Clinton won the Democratic nomination, Yoakum, widely considered to have a [[U.S. Republican Party|Republican]] agenda, contacted [[Sheffield Nelson]], Clinton's opponent in the 1990 gubernatorial race. Yoakum arranged a meeting between Nelson and Broaddrick, who resisted Yoakum's and Nelson's push that she go public. Yoakum secretly taped the conversation and wrote a letter summarizing the allegations, which began to circulate within Republican circles. The story reached the ''[[New York Times]]'' and the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' in October 1992, but the papers dropped the story after Broaddrick refused to talk to reporters and Yoakum refused to release the recording. In the fall of 1997, Paula Jones's private investigators tried to talk to Broaddrick at her home, also secretly taping the conversation.Weiss, Philip. (April 19, 1999). [http://observer.com/1999/04/nbcs-vetting-of-juanita-broaddrick-clintons-accuser-discusses-agonizing-weeks-as-nbc-dragged-it-out/ "NBC’s Vetting of Juanita Broaddrick: Clinton’s Accuser Discusses Agonizing Weeks as NBC Dragged It Out"]. ''New York Observer''. Broaddrick refused to discuss the incident, saying "it was just a horrible horrible thing," and that she "wouldn't relive it for anything." The investigators told her she would likely be subpoenaed if she would not talk to them. Broaddrick said she would deny everything, saying "you can't get to him, and I'm not going to ruin my good name to do it ... there's just absolutely no way anyone can get to him, he's just too vicious."[http://www.mega.nu/ampp/toobin_leaks/5.pdf transcript of conversation] recorded by Rick Lambert Broaddrick was subpoenaed in the Jones suit soon after and submitted an affidavit denying that Clinton had made "any sexual advances". The recording of Broaddrick's conversation with the investigators was leaked to the press, but Broaddrick continued to refuse to speak to reporters. Despite Broaddrick's denial in her affidavit, Jones' lawyers included Yoakum's letter and Broaddrick's name in a 1998 filing. The letter suggested that the Clintons had bought Broaddrick's silence, describing a phone call where Broaddrick's husband asked Yoakum to say the incident never happened and said that he intended to ask Clinton "for a couple of big favors."Yoakum, David (December 23, 1998). [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/politics/special/clinton/stories/lettertext122398.htm "Letter About Jane Doe #5"]. ''The Washington Post''. This, along with the discrepancy between the letter and Broaddrick's affidavit, attracted the attention of independent counsel [[Kenneth Starr]], who was investigating Clinton for obstruction of justice. After being approached by the FBI, Broaddrick consulted her son, a lawyer, who told her she could not lie to federal investigators. After Starr granted her [[legal immunity|immunity]],{{cite web|url=http://www.mediaite.com/online/hacked-clinton-email-reveals-strategy-to-refute-juanita-broaddricks-rape-claims/|title=Hacked Clinton Email Reveals Strategy to Refute Juanita Broaddrick's Rape Claims|publisher=Mediaite}} thus assuring that she would not be prosecuted for perjury regarding her affidavit in the Jones case, Broaddrick recanted the affidavit. However, she insisted that Clinton had not pressured or bribed her in any way, and so Starr concluded that the story was not relevant to his investigation and his report only mentioned the recanting in a footnote. ===1999=== Rumors continued to circulate in tabloids and on talk radio, now with Broaddrick's name attached. Broaddrick was upset by a tabloid report that she had been paid to keep quiet, and decided to agree to an interview with NBC's [[Lisa Myers]]. Myers interviewed her on January 20, 1999, the day after [[Impeachment and acquittal of Bill Clinton|Clinton was impeached]]. The interview only aired on February 24, 1999, 35 days later and after Clinton had been acquitted on February 12. NBC was accused of intentionally sitting on the story and invoking unusually demanding standards of corroboration until the impeachment process ended. Broaddrick and another source said NBC gathered the key corroborating evidence within 10 days of the interview, NBC assistant producer Chris Giglio said it may have taken him 14 days—in either case, while the impeachment process was ongoing. Though the story was unaired, at least one Republican senator reportedly invoked it to convince undecided Republicans to vote for impeachment. While NBC waited to air the interview, Broaddrick was approached by [[Dorothy Rabinowitz]], who wrote for the ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' editorial page. Upset with NBC's delay, Broaddrick agreed to speak with Rabinowitz, and the story debuted on the ''Wall Street Journal'''s editorial page on February 19.Editorial Commentary, Dorothy Rabinowitz; February 19, 1999; Page A18. NBC aired Myers' interview soon after. ===Clinton response to allegations=== On Friday night, February 19, 1999, Clinton's attorney, [[David E. Kendall|David Kendall]], denied the allegations on Clinton's behalf. Kendall stated: "Any allegation that the president assaulted Mrs. Broaddrick more than 20 years ago is absolutely false. Beyond that, we're not going to comment."{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/ALLPOLITICS/stories/1999/02/20/assault.allegation/|title=CNN – White House denies allegations of 1978 sexual assault by Clinton – February 20, 1999|publisher=}} Clinton himself did not say anything on the matter. When asked about Broaddrick's claims at a news conference on February 24, 1999, Clinton said: "Well, my counsel has made a statement about the ... issue, and I have nothing to add to it." Clinton has never been charged with anything in connection with Broaddrick's allegations. ===Public and press reactions=== Because of the time elapsed since the alleged incident and the nature of acquaintance rape cases, there was limited corroborating evidence and so the allegations rested on Broaddrick's testimony. Because she had filed and then recanted an affidavit saying there was no assault, some thought she was not credible. According to the ''[[The New York Times|New York Times]]'' in 1999, the problems with Broaddrick's accusations were that "There is no physical evidence to verify it. No one else was present during the alleged encounter in a Little Rock hotel room nearly 21 years ago. The hotel has since closed. And Mrs. Broaddrick denied the encounter in an affidavit in January 1998 in the Paula Jones case, in which she was known only as ''Jane Doe No. 5.'' Through all those years, she refused to come forward. When pressed by the Jones lawyers, she denied the allegation. And now, she has recanted that denial." In March 1999 [[Slate magazine|''Slate'' magazine]] ran a much-cited analysis piece, called "Is Juanita Broaddrick Telling the Truth?", that gave possible grounds upon which Broaddrick should be believed, or should not be believed, regarding each of a number of key points. On the disbelief side, it was suggested the five people that said Broaddrick had confided in them soon after the incident could be lying. Rogers and Darden had an independent reason to dislike Clinton: as they notified NBC, Clinton had commuted the life sentence of the man who killed their father. The disbelief argument proposes that they may have a grudge against Clinton. Even if the confidants were telling the truth, skeptics noted that Broaddrick could have been lying when she originally confided in them. Some details in Broaddrick's account corresponded with other women's allegations. In an interview that emerged after Broaddrick's allegations, [[Elizabeth Ward Gracen]] said that Clinton bit her lip during a consensual encounter that became rough.Isikoff, Michael (May 30, 2000). ''Uncovering Clinton''. Three Rivers Press. p. 256 Broaddrick said that after the assault, Clinton told her not to worry about pregnancy because childhood [[mumps]] had rendered him sterile. When contacted about the issue, [[Gennifer Flowers]], who Clinton later admitted to a sexual relationship with, agreed that Clinton had thought he couldn't have children.''The Weekly Standard''. (February 20, 1999). [http://www.weeklystandard.com/Content/Protected/Articles/000/000/010/352lwsba.asp "A Case of the Mumps?"]. In March 1999, shortly after the allegations publicly aired, 56% of Americans believed the allegations were false, while a third believed that Broaddrick's allegation of rape was at least possibly true. Similarly, 29% of the public felt the press should continue to cover the story, while 66% felt that the media should stop pursuing the story.Holland, Keating (March 1, 1999). [http://www.cnn.com/ALLPOLITICS/stories/1999/03/01/poll/ "Poll: Most believe media should lay off Broaddrick allegation"]. CNN. The public and media had "scandal fatigue" from the [[Sexual misconduct allegations against Bill Clinton|repeated sexual misconduct allegations against Clinton]] and, after his impeachment and acquittal, many felt the charges had nowhere to go.Kurtz, Howard (March 1, 1999). [https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/1999/03/01/no-rest-for-the-scandal-weary/81fd7680-4339-4348-9a0e-ef43d65487a6/ "No Rest for the Scandal-Weary"]. ''Washington Post''. Many reporters had encountered the story while it was being disseminated by Republican activists and felt they had already looked into it.Walsh, Joan (February 20, 1999). [https://www.salon.com/1999/02/20/cov_20news_2/ "The Ugliest Story Yet"]. ''[[Salon (website)|Salon]]''. [[Jack Nelson (journalist)|Jack Nelson]], Washington bureau chief of the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', said "This is a story that's been knocked down and discredited so many times ... [E]veryone's taken a slice of it, and after looking at it, everyone's knocked it down. The woman has changed her story about whether it happened. It just wasn't credible." Julia Malone, a [[Cox Communications]] reporter, became frustrated by what she perceived as media neglect of the story and held a National Press Club panel on the issue entitled "Too Hot for a 'Scandal-Weary' New Media to Handle?" [[Sam Donaldson]] of [[ABC News]] said he was frustrated over his fellow reporters' unwillingness to press Clinton to respond to the allegations: Clinton refused to comment when Donaldson asked about the allegations, and no one else would press the issue. Judgement on the Broaddrick matter has varied among book-length treatments of the Bill Clinton years. [[Joe Conason]] and [[Gene Lyons]]' book ''[[The Hunting of the President]]'' argued that Broaddrick's claim is not credible, noting that the FBI had found evidence for the allegations "inconclusive". [[Michael Isikoff]]'s book, ''Uncovering Clinton'', stated that Clinton's lawyers figured that he might well have had consensual, extramarital sex with Broaddrick, but they did not believe he would have forced himself on her. [[Christopher Hitchens]]' book, ''[[No One Left to Lie To]]'', argued that Broaddrick's claim is credible and shows similarities to [[Paula Jones]]' later allegation of sexual harassment.{{cite web|url=http://www.salon.com/1999/06/07/hitchens/|title=The (un)friendly witness of Christopher Hitchens|first=Charles|last=Taylor|publisher=}} ==Aftermath== Broaddrick filed a lawsuit against Clinton in December 1999 to obtain documents that the [[White House]] may have gathered about her, claiming its refusal to accede to her demand for such documents violated the [[Privacy Act of 1974]]. Her lawyer was conservative judicial activist [[Larry Klayman]], head of [[Judicial Watch]].{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/1999/ALLPOLITICS/stories/12/20/broaddrick.suit/index.html?_s=PM:ALLPOLITICS|title=Juanita Broaddrick sues Clinton Administration over alleged 'smear campaign' |date=December 20, 1999|publisher=CNN}} The suit was dismissed by U.S. District Court Judge [[Henry H. Kennedy, Jr.]] in March 2001. The judge ruled that the Privacy Act did not apply in this case and that Broaddrick had failed to show evidence that the [[U.S. Department of Justice]] had improperly released documents about her.Josh Gerstein, [http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/story?id=121718 "White House Wag: Courts Back Clinton"], ABC News, April 2, 2001. The lawsuit did not ask for money, and indeed unlike many of the women involved in Bill Clinton instances, Broaddrick did not seek out financial settlements, publishing deals, or a role as a celebrity. During that time, Broaddrick's business was audited by the [[Internal Revenue Service|IRS]] which she charged was retaliation: "I do not believe this was coincidence," Broaddrick declared, "I do not think our number just came up."''Their Lives: The Women Targeted by the Clinton Machine''. World Ahead Publishing, 2005. {{ISBN|9780974670133}} p. 241. As the [[United States Senate election in New York, 2000]] unfolded, in which Hillary was a candidate, Broaddrick published an [[open letter]] to her, denouncing her alleged role in covering for her husband's alleged attack.{{cite web|url=http://www.apfn.org/apfn/Juanita.htm|title=AN OPEN LETTER TO HILLARY CLINTON BY JUANITA BROADDRICK|website=www.apfn.org |accessdate=June 15, 2018}} The Broaddricks divorced in 2004. David Broaddrick had opposed her going public with her rape story in 1999. Juanita Broaddrick felt, according to a 2005 book, that the publicity around the ''Dateline'' interview contributed significantly to the end of her second marriage. She says she also developed a fear of enclosed spaces as a result of what happened. In 2008 Broaddrick sold her nursing home business and retired,[http://thehill.com/blogs/ballot-box/presidential-races/264988-bill-clinton-rape-accuser-hillary-tried-to-silence-me "Bill Clinton rape accuser: Hillary 'tried to silence' me"], ''The Hill'', January 6, 2016. having done well as a businesswoman. She continues to live in Van Buren, on a 23-acre farm.[https://www.buzzfeed.com/katiejmbaker/juanita-broaddrick-wants-to-be-believed "Juanita Broaddrick wants to be believed"], BuzzFeed, August 14, 2016 ==Renewed attention during the 2016 U.S. presidential campaign== Broaddrick resurrected her rape claims on Twitter during the [[United States presidential election, 2016]], as Hillary Clinton was the Democratic nominee for president. In this context, the Broaddrick case has often brought about unease on the part of people who are generally supportive of the Clintons. In an October 2016 recap of the case, [[Dylan Matthews]] of [[Vox (website)|Vox]] said: "The basic answer is that some of the claims [against Bill Clinton] appear more credible than others. There are three main accusers [the others being Jones and Willey], of whom it seems by far the most credible—based on the publicly available evidence—is Broaddrick." Matthews continues: "Given the prevailing view among many progressives—including Hillary Clinton—that one should default to believing rape accusers, the Broaddrick allegation thus poses a problem." [[Michelle Goldberg]] of ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'' wrote in a late 2015 essay, "our rules for talking about sexual assault have changed since the 1990s, when these women were last in the news. Today, feminists have repeatedly and convincingly made the case that when women say they've been sexually assaulted, we should assume they're telling the truth. Particularly when it comes to Broaddrick, it's not easy to square the arguments against believing her with the dominant progressive consensus on trusting victims. This is a tension that people on the right are eager to exploit."[http://www.slate.com/articles/double_x/doublex/2015/12/bill_clinton_s_sexual_past_can_still_hurt_hillary.html "Why Bill's past could still hurt Hillary"], Michelle Goldberg, Slate, December 30, 2015 Many conservative commentators who were typically quite skeptical of sexual assault claims without firm evidence, found Broaddrick's allegations quite believable. As Katie J. M. Baker of [[BuzzFeed]] lamented, "In theory, partisan politics shouldn't play a role in determining whether an alleged rape victim deserves to be heard." Similar observations have been made by Robby Soave of ''[[Reason (magazine)|Reason]]'' magazine.{{cite web|url=http://reason.com/blog/2016/08/17/on-rape-liberals-dont-believe-the-victim|title=On Rape, Liberals Don't 'Believe the Victim' If It's Juanita Broaddrick|date=August 17, 2016|work=Reason}} The now-retired NBC reporter who broadcast her story, Lisa Myers, has said: "No one can objectively look at Juanita's story and not be troubled. One of the things that makes her so credible is who she is—open, straightforward, seemingly guileless." When in late 2015, during a town hall that was an event during the [[Hillary Clinton presidential campaign, 2016]], Hillary Clinton was asked about this question in terms of these women's charges, she responded: "Well, I would say that everyone should be believed at first until they are disbelieved based on evidence."{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/12/03/politics/hillary-clinton-paula-jones-question/index.html|title=Hillary Clinton asked about Paula Jones|author=Eric Bradner and Dan Merica |publisher=CNN}} In January 2016, Broaddrick shared on the social networking site [[Twitter]], "I was 35 years old when Bill Clinton, Ark. Attorney General raped me and Hillary tried to silence me. I am now 73. ... it never goes away." Broaddrick said she was neither a Democrat nor a Republican, but she supported [[Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016|Donald Trump's presidential campaign]]: "He says the things I like to hear." In the [[United States presidential election, 2008]] she voted for [[Barack Obama]] and gave more than $1,000 to his campaign because he was running against Hillary Clinton. She agreed with Trump's injection of Bill Clinton's acknowledged and alleged sexual misdeeds into the campaign. And as the campaign went on, she more and more aligned herself with conservative actions and outlook. On October 8, 2016, in the wake of the [[Donald Trump Access Hollywood controversy|Donald Trump ''Access Hollywood'' controversy]], Trump retweeted Broaddrick's tweets in which she calls Bill Clinton a "rapist" and calls Hillary Clinton's actions "horrific".{{cite news|last1=Nelson|first1=Louis|title=Trump puts Clinton on watch by retweeting Juanita Broaddrick |url=http://www.politico.com/story/2016/10/juanita-broaddrick-trump-twitter-clinton-229387|accessdate=October 9, 2016|work=POLITICO|date=October 8, 2016}}{{cite news|last1=Blake|first1=Aaron|title=Donald Trump just retweeted Juanita Broaddrick calling Bill Clinton a rapist. All bets are now off.|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2016/10/08/donald-trump-just-retweeted-juanita-broaddrick-calling-bill-clinton-a-rapist-all-bets-are-now-off/|accessdate=October 9, 2016|work=Washington Post|date=October 8, 2016}} On October 9 Broaddrick appeared on a panel with Trump, [[Paula Jones]], and [[Kathleen Willey]] (a fourth woman at the panel, [[Kathy Shelton]], had an unrelated grievance against Hillary Clinton) an hour before the second debate between Trump and Clinton in the general election portion of the [[United States presidential election debates, 2016]].{{cite web|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2016/10/donald-trump-bill-clinton-accusers-229441?lo=ap_a2|title=Trump hosts surprise panel with Bill Clinton's accusers |work=Politico}} Broaddrick and the others were also in the audience during the debate, as was Bill Clinton, although debate organizers kept them in separate areas.{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/2016-presidential-debates/trump-planned-debate-stunt-invited-bill-clinton-accusers-rattle-hillary-n663481|title=Trump wanted Bill Clinton's sex accusers to sit with family at debate|publisher=NBC News}} The Trump campaign said it had paid for Broaddrick's travel to the debate.{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-elections/donald-trump-ally-paid-clinton-sexual-assault-critic-a7353326.html|title=Donald Trump ally 'paid Clinton sexual assault critic'|date=October 10, 2016|work=The Independent}} ==#MeToo and re-evaluation in 2017–18== In 2017, in the wake of [[Harvey Weinstein sexual abuse allegations]], Broaddrick criticized 1990s Bill Clinton paramour [[Monica Lewinsky]] for aligning herself with the [[Me Too (hashtag)|#MeToo movement]], saying, "I have always felt sad for you, but where were you when we needed you?" Broaddrick added, "I always felt she was a victim. I only wish she had spoken up in '99 when I was going thru so much persecution after my interview on ''NBC Dateline''."{{cite web|url=http://www.newsweek.com/juanita-broaddrick-monica-lewinskys-metoo-your-silence-was-deafening-688924|title=One of Bill Clinton's accusers slams another over the #MeToo campaign|date=October 19, 2017|website=Newsweek|access-date=November 17, 2017}} Once again media attention focused on the allegations against Clinton, including those from Broaddrick.{{cite web|url=http://freebeacon.com/politics/liberals-journalists-call-reevaluation-bill-clinton-sexual-assault-claims/amp/|title=While Women Come Out with Harassment Claims, Liberals Are Taking Another Look at One of Their Own|date=November 14, 2017|website=Washington Free Beacon|access-date=November 17, 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/entertainment/archive/2017/11/reckoning-with-bill-clintons-sex-crimes/545729/|title=Bill Clinton: A Reckoning|first=Caitlin|last=Flanagan |date=November 13, 2017|work=The Atlantic|accessdate=June 15, 2018}} Matthews wrote that "America's ongoing national reckoning with sexual assault and sexual harassment by powerful men now has liberals and Democrats reconsidering the legacy of one of party's most important figures of the past quarter-century: President Bill Clinton." Caitlin Flanagan of ''[[The Atlantic]]'' wrote "Yet let us not forget the sex crimes of which the younger, stronger Bill Clinton was very credibly accused in the 1990s. Juanita Broaddrick reported that ..." before recapping the case. During an [[NPR]] interview Flanagan said, "And so there were a series of women throughout the course of his presidency who came forward with accounts of things they said he did to them which really mirror the kinds of things we're looking at now in the very worst of the cases. Juanita Broaddrick, most prominently, said that he raped her very violently in a way that is quite like the Harvey Weinstein accusations in terms of the hotel room and the suddenness and the bleak horror of it all."{{cite web|url=http://wfae.org/post/rethinking-bill-clinton-amid-sexual-harassment-debates|title=Rethinking Bill Clinton Amid Sexual Harassment Debates|publisher=WFAE|accessdate=June 15, 2018}} Goldberg wrote an op-ed in the ''New York Times'' entitled "I Believe Juanita", where she said, "In this #MeToo moment, when we're reassessing decades of male misbehavior and turning open secrets into exposes, we should look clearly at the credible evidence that Juanita Broaddrick told the truth when she accused Clinton of raping her. But revisiting the Clinton scandals in light of today's politics is complicated as well as painful."{{cite web|url=https://mobile.nytimes.com/2017/11/13/opinion/juanita-broaddrick-bill-clinton.html|title=Opinion – I Believe Juanita|website=New York Times|access-date=November 17, 2017}} Following the allegations made against Alabama senate candidate [[Roy Moore]], Broaddrick said, "All victims matter. It doesn't matter if you're a Democrat or a Republican ... We all have the right to be believed."{{cite web|url=http://insider.foxnews.com/amp/article/58987|title=Juanita Broaddrick on Roy Moore: 'I Hope Clintons Get What's Due to Them' Too|publisher=Fox News|access-date=November 17, 2017}} In January 2018 Broaddrick self-published a memoir, co-authored by Nick Lulli, with the title ''You'd Better Put Some Ice On That: How I Survived Being Raped By Bill Clinton''.{{cite web|url=http://katv.com/news/local/juanita-broaddrick-releases-new-book-recounting-allege-rape-by-bill-clinton|title=Juanita Broaddrick releases new book recounting allege rape by Bill Clinton|publisher=KATV|accessdate=June 15, 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/entertainment/2018/01/09/clinton-rape-accuser-juanita-broaddrick-slams-oprah-winfreys-celebrated-golden-globes-speech.amp.html|title=Clinton rape accuser Juanita Broaddrick slams Oprah Winfrey's celebrated Golden Globes speech|first=Stephanie|last=Nolasco |date=January 9, 2018|publisher=Fox News|accessdate=June 15, 2018}} ==See also== {{Wikiquote}} * [[Linda Tripp]] * [[Monica Lewinsky]] * [[Sally Perdue]] * ''[[Their Lives: The Women Targeted by the Clinton Machine]]'' ==References== {{Ibid|date=November 2018}} {{reflist|30em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Broaddrick, Juanita}} [[Category:Place of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Van Buren, Arkansas]] [[Category:American nurses]] [[Category:American women nurses]] [[Category:American nursing administrators]] [[Category:American businesspeople]] [[Category:Clinton administration controversies]] [[Category:Controversies of the United States presidential election, 2016]] [[Category:Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016]]

{{Infobox park | name = Embarcadero Plaza | image = Justin Herman Plaza from Steuart Tower.JPG | image_size = | image_alt = | image_caption = The plaza in 2009 | map = United States San Francisco Central#United States San Francisco Bay Area#California | map_width = | type = | location = | nearest_city = | coordinates = {{coord|37.7949|N|122.3948|W|display=title;inline}} | area = | created = | operator = | visitation_num = | status = | designation = | open = 1972 | publictransit = [[BART]] and [[San Francisco Municipal Railway|Muni]], {{bart|Embarcadero}} station }} '''Embarcadero Plaza''', previously known as '''Justin Herman Plaza''' from its opening in 1972 until 2017, is a {{convert|1.23|acre|abbr=on|adj=on}} plaza near the intersection of [[Market Street (San Francisco)|Market]] and [[Embarcadero (San Francisco)|Embarcadero]] in [[San Francisco]]'s [[Financial District, San Francisco|Financial District]], in the [[U.S. state]] of [[California]]. It is owned by [[Boston Properties]], who acquired the neighboring [[Embarcadero Center]] office, hotel, and retail complex in 1998.
==Design== {{quotebox|align=left|width=25em|text=The Ferry Building Park could be a great open space with canals, lagoons, and fountains that would revive the marine flavor by actually bringing the Bay back into the area. The atmosphere of European ports could be injected with handsome paving, sidewalk cafes, and fine restaurants. The freeway should be painted dark, and large trees should be planted to suppress its sight and its sounds. Difficult as all this may be, establish the Ferry Building Park area as a vibrant, alive, colorful place, used by day and at night, and it will send a tingle up the spine of Market Street. |author=Halprin, Carter, and Rockrise |source=''What to do About Market Street'' (1962)<ref name=1962market />}} The design of Embarcadero Plaza is credited to [[Don Carter (architect)|Don Carter]] (principal-in-charge) with help from [[Mario J. Ciampi]] and [[John Savage Bolles|John Bolles]]. The original concept was devised by [[Lawrence Halprin]], who described five distinct districts of Market Street in the 1962 report ''What to do About Market Street'' starting at the Embarcadero and ending at Van Ness.<ref name=1962market>{{cite report |url=https://archive.org/details/whattodoaboutmar00livi/page/31 |title=What to Do About Market Street: A prospectus for a development program prepared for the Market Street Development Project, an associate of SPUR: The San Francisco Planning and Urban Renewal Association |chapter=The Look of Market Street |pages=23–34 |author1=Halprin, Lawrence |author2=Carter, Donald Ray |author3=Rockrise, George T. |publisher=Livingston and Blayney, City and Regional Planners |year=1962 |accessdate=15 October 2018}}</ref> In retrospect, Halprin's vision for Market was described as a "pedestrian-oriented series of linked civic spaces"<ref>{{cite web |url=https://tclf.org/sites/default/files/microsites/halprinlegacy/justin-herman-plaza.html |title=Justin Herman Plaza, 1962-71 |website=The Landscape Architecture of Lawrence Halprin |publisher=The Cultural Landscape Foundation |accessdate=15 October 2018}}</ref> which were later realized as the open spaces running from Embarcadero Plaza (in the northeast) to [[United Nations Plaza (San Francisco)|UN Plaza]] in the southwest. Halprin described an early concept for what he called Ferry Building Park in the 1962 ''Market Street'' report, proposing to bring [[San Francisco Bay]] and the original harbor closer to Market, as "the [Embarcadero] Freeway and the Ferry building have created an impenetrable barrier, at street level, to one of San Francisco's most priceless assets – its marine setting" and offering ways to minimize the visual and aural impact of the double-decked freeway.<ref name=1962market />
[[File:I-480 from Hyatt Regency ca 1988.jpg|thumb|right|View of ''[[Vaillancourt Fountain]]'' and Justin Herman Plaza in 1988, matching initial 1972 configuration. Note double-deck [[Embarcadero Freeway]] separating plaza from waterfront.]] The controversial ''[[Vaillancourt Fountain]]'' dominates the northeast end of the plaza.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://sfrecpark.org/destination/justin-herman-embarcadero-plaza/ | title=Justin Herman – Embarcadero Plaza | publisher=[[San Francisco Recreation & Parks Department]] | accessdate=August 3, 2013}}</ref> The large plaza could accommodate large crowds, and the roaring fountain was designed to drown out noise from the [[Embarcadero Freeway]], which was completed in 1959 and ran along the east side of the plaza from its opening in 1972 until the freeway was torn down in 1991.<ref name=SFC-091103 /><ref name=SFC-170816>{{cite news |url=https://www.sfchronicle.com/bayarea/place/article/Testing-the-waters-for-bringing-the-Vaillancourt-11821748.php |title=Testing the waters for bringing the Vaillancourt Fountain back to life |author=King, John |date=August 16, 2017 |newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle |accessdate=16 October 2018}}</ref> ''[[La Chiffonnière]]'' is also installed in the plaza, closer to Market.<ref name=SFC-171018>{{cite news |url=https://www.sfchronicle.com/bayarea/place/article/Justim-Herman-Plaza-needs-more-than-name-change-12285745.php |title=Justin Herman Plaza needs more than name change |author=King, John |date=October 18, 2017 |newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle |accessdate=16 October 2018}}</ref>
A [[bocce ball]] court was built using private donations in 2010.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.sfgate.com/outdoors/article/Bay-Area-bocce-ball-sites-2327824.php |title=Bay Area bocce ball sites |author1=May, Meredith |author2=Whiting, Sam |author3=Guthrie, Julian |date=October 9, 2011 |newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle |accessdate=16 October 2018}}</ref>
===Reception=== During the debate over changing the name, ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' urban spaces critic John King called it "a stark concrete landscape" and added "there's no earthly reason you would want to be there."<ref name=SFC-171018 /> In an earlier article published just after Halprin's death in 2009, King noted that Embarcadero Plaza was "oversize and stiff, unable to adjust to the changing urban scene on all sides."<ref name=SFC-091103>{{cite news |url=https://www.sfgate.com/entertainment/article/Lawrence-Halprin-s-living-legacy-in-S-F-3211095.php |title=Lawrence Halprin's living legacy in S.F. |author=King, John |date=November 3, 2009 |newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle |accessdate=16 October 2018}}</ref>
==History== The plaza, located at the eastern end of Market Street, opened in 1972. It was originally named for [[M. Justin Herman]], executive director of the [[San Francisco Redevelopment Agency]] from 1959 to 1971.
In 2017, County Supervisor [[Aaron Peskin]] introduced a resolution to rename the site Embarcadero Plaza, citing Herman's role in displacing poor and minority residents from the [[Western Addition, San Francisco|Western Addition]], [[Fillmore District, San Francisco|Fillmore]], [[Chinatown, San Francisco|Chinatown]], and [[South of Market, San Francisco|South of Market]] neighborhoods while presiding over the San Francisco Redevelopment Agency.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.sfgate.com/politics/article/SF-Supervisor-Peskin-ramps-up-drive-to-rename-11415576.php |title=SF Supervisor Peskin ramps up drive to rename Justin Herman Plaza |author=Dineen, J.K. |date=July 27, 2017 |newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle |accessdate=September 11, 2017}}</ref> The [[San Francisco Board of Supervisors]] passed the resolution unanimously on September 19, 2017. The name Embarcadero Plaza will be temporary until a new official name can be decided upon.<ref name="nbc-19sep2017">{{cite news|title=SF Leaders Vote Unanimously to Rename Justin Herman Plaza|url=http://www.nbcbayarea.com/news/local/SF-Leaders-Vote-Unanimously-to-Rename-Justin-Herman-Plaza-445886603.html|accessdate=September 19, 2017|newspaper=[[NBC Bay Area]]|date=September 19, 2017}}</ref> The Board's resolution is nonbinding, as the authority to change the name rests with the [[San Francisco Recreation & Parks Department|San Francisco Recreation and Park Commission]]. Peskin stated he had received an unsolicited text from the owner, Boston Properties, which said they would cover the cost of replacing the plaque bearing Herman's name.<ref name=SFC-170921>{{cite news |url=http://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/SF-supervisors-want-Justin-Herman-Plaza-to-get-a-12210332.php |title=SF supervisors want Justin Herman's name yanked off plaza |author=Swan, Rachel |date=September 19, 2017 |newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle |accessdate=September 21, 2017}}</ref>
The Recreation & Parks Commission voted 4–2 to remove Justin Herman's name on November 16, 2017. An earlier vote in October ended in a 3–3 tie after one of the commissioners (who had favored removal of the name) left the meeting before the vote was held.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://sf.curbed.com/2017/11/17/16669802/justin-herman-plaza-name-sf |title=City officially removes Justin Herman's name from plaza |author=Brinklow, Adam |date=17 November 2017 |work=SF Curbed |accessdate=15 October 2018}}</ref><ref name=SFE-171019>{{cite news |url=http://www.sfexaminer.com/rec-park-commission-votes-remove-justin-hermans-name-plaza/ |title=UPDATE: Commission’s vote to remove Justin Herman’s name from plaza later declared invalid |author=Sabatini, Joshua |date=October 19, 2017 |newspaper=San Francisco Examiner |accessdate=15 October 2018}}</ref> [[David Johnson (photographer)|David Johnson]], a photographer who documented life in the Western Addition prior to SFRA's redevelopment, is a leading candidate for the renaming of the plaza.<ref name=SFE-171019 />
==Usage== [[File:DSC00235 (6286183437).jpg|thumb|left|[[Occupy San Francisco]] encampment (2011)]] The plaza is frequented by nearby office workers on lunch break and by families with small children. Free daytime concerts occur frequently in the summer, and an ice skating rink is set up for winter months.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tFVLm-A5hEgC&pg=PA73&lpg=PA73 |title=People Places: Design Guidelines for Urban Open Space |chapter=1. Urban Plazas, Case Studies: 9. Justin Herman Plaza: Grand Public Place—the City Plaza |editor1=Marcus, Clare Cooper |editor2=Francis, Carolyn |author1=Marcus, Clare Cooper |author2=Francis, Carolyn |author3=Russell, Robert |author-link1=Clare Cooper Marcus |edition=Second |date=1998 |publisher=John Wiley & Sons, Inc. |location=New York, New York |isbn=0-471-28833-0 |pages=73–74 |accessdate=16 October 2018}}</ref> In 1987, during [[The Joshua Tree Tour]], [[U2]] held a free concert in Justin Herman Plaza to "Save the Yuppies" following the [[Black Monday (1987)|Black Monday financial crisis]] in October. During the finale of the impromptu concert, [[Bono]] spray-painted graffiti on ''Vaillancourt Fountain'', for which he was fined.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://hoodline.com/2017/09/save-the-yuppies-u2-s-free-1987-concert-in-justin-herman-plaza |title='Save The Yuppies:' U2's Free 1987 Concert In Justin Herman Plaza |author=Sisto, Carrie |date=September 10, 2017 |work=Hoodline |accessdate=16 October 2018}}</ref>
[[File:Feathers everywhere (6879653299).jpg|thumb|right|Great San Francisco Pillow Fight (2012)]] During the early 1990s, the plaza was better known as EMB, one of the world's premier [[street skateboarding]] sites.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.sfgate.com/entertainment/article/No-easy-skate-S-F-is-no-longer-shredder-heaven-2571297.php |title=No easy skate: S.F. is no longer shredder heaven |author=Jensen, Travis |date=March 9, 2007 |newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle |accessdate=15 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.complex.com/sports/2013/08/iconic-skate-spots-that-no-longer-exist/emb |title=10 Iconic Skate Spots That No Longer Exist: 6. EMB |author=Elliott, Templeton |date=August 9, 2013 |work=Complex |accessdate=15 October 2018}}</ref> Formal athletic ceremonies and rallies have also occurred in the plaza, including the retirement of [[Joe Montana]] (1995), attended by an estimated 25,000 people;<ref>{{cite news |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1995-04-19/sports/sp-56243_1_san-francisco |title=Montana Goes Home to Say Goodby |author=Plaschke, Bill |date=April 19, 1995 |newspaper=Los Angeles Times |accessdate=16 October 2018}}</ref> the commemoration of [[Barry Bonds]] becoming the [[List of Major League Baseball career home run leaders|all-time home run leader]] (2007);<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.sfgate.com/sports/article/San-Francisco-honors-Barry-Bonds-for-Giant-2524903.php |title=San Francisco honors Barry Bonds for Giant accomplishments |author=Wildermuth, John |date=August 24, 2007 |newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle |accessdate=16 October 2018}}</ref> and as the site of Super Bowl City, a "fan village" for attendees of [[Super Bowl 50]] (2016) at [[Levi's Stadium]] in distant [[Santa Clara, California|Santa Clara]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/Super-Bowl-City-fan-village-will-fill-Justin-6214087.php |title=Super Bowl City fan village will fill Justin Herman Plaza |author=Knight, Heather |date=April 21, 2015 |newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle |accessdate=16 October 2018}}</ref> Because of its size, the plaza is also frequently used for political rallies, including the [[Occupy San Francisco]] protest which took over the plaza for several months in 2011.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/Occupy-SF-regroups-after-raid-clashes-with-cops-2365885.php |title=Occupy SF regroups after raid, clashes with cops |author1=Ho, Vivian |author2=Kane, Will |author3=Colliver, Victoria |date=December 8, 2011 |newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle |accessdate=16 October 2018}}</ref>
===Recurring events=== The monthly [[Critical Mass (cycling)|Critical Mass]] bicycle rides have started from the plaza since September 1992.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/Critical-Mass-bike-movement-at-20-years-3897679.php |title=Critical Mass bike movement at 20 years |author=Fimrite, Peter |date=September 26, 2012 |newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle |accessdate=15 October 2018}}</ref> Since 2006,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/SAN-FRANCISCO-Hundreds-attend-mass-pillow-fight-2522981.php |title=SAN FRANCISCO / Hundreds attend mass pillow fight |author=Hoge, Patrick |date=February 14, 2006 |newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle |accessdate=15 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://goldengatexpress.org/2017/02/15/san-francisco-blows-off-steam-at-12th-annual-valentines-day-pillow-fight/ |title=San Francisco blows off steam at 12th annual Valentine's Day pillow fight |author=Riquelme, Rita Berrios |date=February 15, 2017 |newspaper=Golden Gate Xpress |accessdate=15 October 2018}}</ref> on [[Valentine's Day]], the plaza is the site of the [[Great San Francisco Pillow Fight]], an unsponsored annual [[pillow fight flash mob]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://sanfrancisco.cbslocal.com/2014/02/14/sf-pillow-fight-evolves-from-intimate-brawl-to-full-scale-melee/ |title=SF Valentine’s Day Pillow Fight Evolves From Intimate Brawl To Full-Scale Melee |date=February 14, 2014 |work=KPIX 5 CBS SF BayArea |accessdate=15 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://abc7.com/society/1-knocked-unconscious-in-san-francisco-pillow-fight/519257/ |title=1 knocked unconscious in San Francisco pillow fight |author=Gulezian, Lisa Amin |date=February 15, 2015 |work=ABC 7 News |accessdate=15 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nbcbayarea.com/news/local/Massive-Valentines-Day--Pillowfight-Returns-to-San-Francisco--368798931.html |title=Massive Valentine's Day Pillow Fight Hits San Francisco |date=February 14, 2016 |work=NBC Bay Area |accessdate=15 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nbcbayarea.com/news/local/Nothing-Says-Happy-Valentines-Day-Like-a-Pillow-Fight-San-Franciscans-Say-Yes-413753393.html |title=Nothing Says Happy Valentine's Day Like a Pillow Fight? San Franciscans Say Yes |date=February 14, 2017 |work=NBC Bay Area |accessdate=15 October 2018}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Justin Herman Plaza}} {{Portal|California}} * {{cite web |url=https://sfgov.legistar.com/View.ashx?M=F&ID=5479971&GUID=6BDFA826-ECC5-4A10-8A28-7159F015DAAA |title=Resolution No. 354-17 |date=11 September 2017 |publisher=San Francisco Board of Supervisors |accessdate=16 August 2018}} * {{cite report |url=http://sfrecpark.org/wp-content/uploads/101917-minutes.pdf |title=Minutes |date=October 19, 2017 |publisher=San Francisco Recreation and Park Commission |accessdate=16 October 2018 |pages=29–31 |chapter=Justin Herman Plaza}} * {{cite report |url=http://sfrecpark.org/wp-content/uploads/111617-minutes.pdf |title=Minutes |date=November 16, 2017 |publisher=San Francisco Recreation and Park Commission |accessdate=16 October 2018 |pages=10–18 |chapter=Justin Herman Plaza}}

revision.text:
{{notability|date=July 2010}} The '''Lakes District Technocity'''(established in 2004) is a science park located on the campus of [[Süleyman Demirel University]]. The technocity is a full member of [[International Association of Science Parks]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.iasp.ws/publico/index.jsp?enl=3 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-06-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120801192432/http://www.iasp.ws/publico/index.jsp?enl=3 |archivedate=2012-08-01 |df= }}</ref> The science park occupies 112000 squaremeters area.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.iasp.ws/publico/index.jsp?enl=3 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-06-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120801192432/http://www.iasp.ws/publico/index.jsp?enl=3 |archivedate=2012-08-01 |df= }}</ref>
The activities of the technocity include Energy and Renewable Energy, Internet Technology and Services / E-Business, Plasma Technology, and Environment Technologies.
As of 2010, 57% of firms on the tecnocity involved in the area of computer software industry.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://teknokent.sdu.edu.tr/tr/sirketler.php |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-06-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110518214100/http://teknokent.sdu.edu.tr/tr/sirketler.php |archivedate=2011-05-18 |df= }}</ref>
==History==
The technocity made its first export(plasma sensors to Saudi Arabia) in 2008.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://basin.sdu.edu.tr/haber/2008/3681/3681.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-06-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120713063045/http://basin.sdu.edu.tr/haber/2008/3681/3681.htm |archivedate=2012-07-13 |df= }}</ref>
== Shareholders ==
The following entities are shareholders of the park:<ref>{{cite web |url=http://teknokent.sdu.edu.tr/tr2/gbt.php |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-06-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100516182615/http://teknokent.sdu.edu.tr/tr2/gbt.php |archivedate=2010-05-16 |df= }}</ref>
{| class="wikitable" |+ ! Shareholder !! Ownership % |- | [[Süleyman Demirel University]] | 80 |- | [[Isparta Chamber of Industry and Trade]] | 10 |- | [[Isparta Mercantile Exchange]] | 5 |- | [[Mehmet Akif Ersoy University]] | 2 |- | [[Burdur Chamber of Industry and Trade]] | 1 |- | [[Burdur General Assembly of Province]] | 1 |- | ISBAŞ Inc. | 1 |}
==Facilities==
===Sciences Laboratories=== * Analytics Laboratory * Gama Spectroscope Laboratory * HPLC Center Research Laboratory * Hydrobiology Laboratory * Organic Chemistry Laboratory
===Engineering Laboratories=== {{colbegin|colwidth=25em}} * Engine Laboratory * Hidrolics Laboratory * Transportation Laboratory * Fluids Laboratory * Floor Mechanics Laboratory * Termodynamics Laboratory * Environmental Engineering Laboratories * Air Pollution Laboratory * Solid Churns Laboratory * Chemical Recycling Laboratory * Textile Engineering Department Laboratory * Textile Laboratory * Textile Engineering Laboratory * Practical Geology Laboratory * Electronics and Communications Department Laboratory * Substance Preparation, Coal Preparation Technology Laboratory * Natural Stone Laboratory * Cross-Section Preparation Laboratory * Geological Engineering Department Laboratory * Geological Substance Microscopy Laboratory * Flotation Laboratory * Mine Administering Laboratory * Mine Laboratory {{colend}}
